introPage.heroTitle: iOS SwiftUI App Development for Liberal Arts Learners
introPage.heroLead: Designed for liberal arts learners to start from zero, enjoy coding, and build apps with confidence.
heroLines: Just 12 weeks, one evening per week,
and become a confident iOS SwiftUI app builder.
learnItems: Build iOS apps independently and publish to the App Store.
Learn Swift and core programming concepts: variables, functions, conditionals, loops, and classes.
Build an ebook-style app around topics you love, like The Little Prince, a photo album, or Tang Poetry.
Work with the latest Swift, Xcode, iOS SDK, and SwiftUI.
Prototype and ship the apps you care about.
Communicate better with engineers and boost team efficiency.
Get comfortable with Xcode and Playground.
Craft polished UI and prototypes with SwiftUI.

cards.title: Live + Recording
lines: Rewatch the videos anytime, no expiry

qaPage.heading: Top 10 iOS App Development Q&A
qaPage.description: Peter Pan answers the most common questions about learning and building iOS apps.

items.title: Keep leveling up
items.body: Ten weeks is just the start—self-learning is key. Each year’s iOS SDK keeps us happily busy. Keep practicing, and ping Peter on FB anytime if you’re stuck.

items.title: Jobs
items.body: Plenty of iOS roles in Taiwan; Peter knows many founders and can recommend you.

items.title: Freelance
items.body: Take on projects to sharpen your skills, grow your portfolio, and earn along the way.

items.title: Start a business
items.body: Publish your own apps, build downloads and ad revenue; a few launches make a standout resume.

items.title: 20% off advanced courses
items.body: Enjoy 20% off Peter’s advanced courses (excludes third-party collaborations). Learning never stops, and Apple ships new tech every year.

plans.title: Student price
plans.subtitle: Students and grads within 1 year
plans.note: Installments available: 2,400 NT each, 3 installments, every 3 weeks.

plans.note: Start with Foundation, then move to the advanced Peter Pan class.

signupPage.title: Apply
signupPage.description: Sign up via Google Form. Payment is by bank transfer—we’ll send account details by email, so be sure to enter a correct email address.
signupPage.formCopy: Submit the form and we’ll email you the bank details and next steps.
signupPage.hint: After submitting, please check your inbox.
signupPage.psText: This course is beginner-friendly. If you already know some coding, check out our other course:
steps: Fill out the Google Form to reserve your spot.
Watch your inbox—we’ll send bank details and confirmation.
Complete the transfer to lock in your seat.

video.title: Build an app in a song’s time
video.description: Creating an app isn’t hard—within one song you can craft a simple Little Prince ebook app.

items.title: Getting close to Xcode
items.description: Learn the all-in-one app development tool, Xcode.

items.title: Swift, the modern app language
items.description: Use Playground to learn Swift and core programming concepts: variables, types, functions, conditionals, loops, classes, and objects.

items.title: Building UIs with SwiftUI
items.description: Create eye-catching app screens with SwiftUI.

items.title: E-book App
items.description: Learn how to build an e-book style app—The Little Prince, Tang Poems, movie library, and more.

items.title: Content switching App
items.description: Apply app logic to switch and navigate content within the UI.

items.title: Colorful Hats App
items.description: A playful app to build and interact with colorful hats.

items.title: Quiz App
items.description: Learn arrays and custom data structures.

items.title: If-Else App – Polaroid
items.description: Practice conditional logic to build an app.

items.title: Multiple-choice App
items.description: Combine core programming skills to build a quiz app.

items.title: Tip Calculator App
items.description: Learn keyboard handling and string-number conversion.

items.title: Ship to App Store
items.description: Learn the steps to publish your app to the App Store.

audiencePage.heading: Who should join
audiencePage.description: Designed for beginners and career-switchers who want to build apps and collaborate better with engineers.
targets: Those who feel unsure about code and want to start from scratch.
Designers/PMs who want to learn coding and app development to collaborate better with engineers.
People who want to create their own apps.
Founders/CEOs who want to understand app technology.
High school students who want app projects in their portfolio for college applications.
Kids (grade 5+) who want to learn fundamentals and build fun iOS apps.

testimonialsPage.title: Student Testimonials
testimonialsPage.subtitle: Real, unfiltered reflections from learners—walk through every step of the journey together.

essays.title: Essays from Peter Pan on iOS App Learning

items.title: Preparation Before Learning Swift iOS App Dev
Ten Q&A About iOS App Development
How to Become an iOS App Wizard
Over 30—Is It Too Late to Learn Code?
9 Tips to Learn Coding Better in Class
When You Strive to Learn Swift, the World Helps
Why We Couldn’t Learn Programming Back Then
13 Ways to Start a Business with iOS Apps
Write Better Swift by Mimicking Apple Examples
Switching Careers in Months: 40 Hours/Week Practice
A Duck Learning to Fly
items.author: Yaya
items.course: iOS App Development for Liberal Arts Learners
paragraphs: I once doubted the raving comments about Peter’s funny teaching. In class I ended up laughing nonstop—he drops “non-important” Easter eggs, gets classmates to admit guilty answers, and uses playful examples to explain tough concepts. Highly recommended.
Peter replies at lightning speed, no matter how late. I once missed class while traveling; he even offered a makeup. Truly kind-hearted.
If you have zero background and weak logic, the pace gets harder later. But if you practice and finish every homework, the sense of achievement far outweighs the frustration.
Thanks to Peter for bringing me into the once “duck‑unreachable” Swift world. For liberal‑arts learners who think code is impossible: step out, fly with him, and you’ll gain more than imagined.

items.title: My iOS Awakening with Peter Pan
items.author: Helen
items.course: iOS App Development for Liberal Arts Learners
paragraphs: Before Peter, I had no coder friends and online/camp courses felt impossible. His intro (in plain language) cleared my first mental barrier.
Class was nothing like I imagined—simple explanations plus cold jokes kept me awake 85% of the time. The course flew by!
Best part: his instant answers on LINE/FB. Learning only works if you practice, and he’s always there when you’re stuck.
Teaching, mentoring, answering—Peter forever!

items.title: Fly into the iOS World with Peter Pan
items.author: Morris
items.course: iOS App Development for Liberal Arts Learners
paragraphs: Ten sessions flew by. If you want an iOS teacher who fits the bill, here’s why:

1) More patience than anyone—ask anytime, he answers softly and clearly.
2) Always up-to-date—he updates slides even the night before to match new SDK changes.
3) 24/7 TA—stuck at midnight? Ping him on LINE/FB; if he’s awake, you’re saved.
4) Low-pressure class—uses fun examples (Penny Tai, childhood toys, jokes) so you learn basics without fear.

items.title: PPAP First Experience
items.author: Buffy
items.course: iOS App Development for Liberal Arts Learners
paragraphs: Wanted to learn something new, so I took Peter Pan’s app class. He’s super approachable (maybe because I sat front row asking nonstop XD). First lesson: “Don’t call me teacher, we’re lifelong friends.” Also: bonus 90s hits sing-alongs.
After work I was tired, but building my first layout felt great. Peter gives huge confidence—always talking about shipping to the App Store (even if I hadn’t finished homework…).
His IF/ELSE examples use everyday scenarios, even glimpses of his life. Later classes humbled me; real practice is needed.

He even bought drinks for everyone in the final class and lets alumni audit again. Truly a saint. If you’re a liberal-arts learner scared by giant curriculums, take Peter’s class to understand fundamentals and bridge gaps with engineers.

items.title: Stepping In
items.author: Shiny
items.course: iOS App Development for Liberal Arts Learners
paragraphs: Peter’s class made me realize I truly like programming. I used to be a “three-minute passion” person, but after summer homework I stopped fearing code and kept digging.
At first I was scared and clueless; his course intro hooked me. Early classes were calm; the first code session had me happily practicing at home.
I used to rely on Peter for every answer—he replies like a computer. Eventually I learned to search and solve on my own, clearing many concepts.
Highlights: his cold jokes are actually funny; he even joins student chats. Also, Water‑bearers are the best and Peter is full of strengths (his joke). Thanks, Peter!

items.title: After the iOS App Course
items.author: Sky
items.course: 彼得潘的 iOS App 程式設計入門
paragraphs: By chance I joined Peter’s Swift course and it became unforgettable. His unwavering love for Swift fills the room—humor plus step-by-step teaching, with rich media in the slides.
He says: “No question is unsolvable.” Homework gets harder, but finishing it reinforces class concepts. Ask in the group or Peter directly; also learn from classmates’ strengths.

As class ended, we parted ways, hoping to cross paths again. If this magic needs a time limit, I wish for 10,000 years. You don’t need to be great to start, but you need to start to be great. Just do it.

items.author: Ming
paragraphs: My company enrolled me for work. I was terrified I wouldn’t understand, but app development wasn’t as hard as imagined. Though slower than classmates with coding backgrounds, Peter patiently answered every question—even after class.
Seeing my own design become a real app was incredibly moving. Even though my job later didn’t require coding, I’m grateful for the confidence and encouragement Peter gave me.

items.author: 小咪
paragraphs: My background is design and I had no clue about code. Peter’s clear teaching made app development approachable. When I hit bugs, he spotted the issue immediately and helped fix it. His warm, sincere teaching feels zero-distance.
With Peter’s help, I can pursue becoming an iOS developer with confidence.
